title: (x) The Blue Bar - Quicksilver {Mark S}
content:
I'm not sure whether I'm proud or embarrassed to have forgotten the name of this. ![:-)](http://web.archive.org/web/20050518125139im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/clipart/happy.gif)   
   
   
 ![blue bar](http://web.archive.org/web/20050518125139im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/39740.jpg)
author: typotect

comments.content: Ok, I found a version of it named Quicky from Opti Fonts. What is the deal with that foundry? I know Mark Simonson was explaining what happened to them but it's still a bit of a blur to me.

Originally, this was a Letraset font called Quicksilver. Letraset never did a digital version of it that I know of. All the existing digital versions are knock-offs.   
   
Opti-Fonts is part of Castcraft, a fairly old Chicago printing firm which is known to older typophiles for its Type Films of Chicago, which marketed a huge library of pirated film fonts.
